class_notes:
(Same as AAS 444W 1)


Not much of a surprise to anyone that the United States holds the world's largest prison 
population, caging more humans than any other nation on earth. The numbers are even more 
troublesome when we consider the policing apparatus that fills the nation's carceral facilities. 
Because of this, the implications for everything else that takes place in that country are vast.
This research and writing, intensive course is designed to introduce students to the burgeoning 
field of carceral studies, focusing largely on the racial, political, economic, and gendered 
dimensions of the carceral state in the United States since its founding to examine how the 
United States has become a world leader in the use of incarceration. Course readings this 
semester cover topics that include: convict labor, criminalization, conquest and imperialism, 
and policing.
